statement.p: The radiator in a car is filled with a solution of 70 antifreeze and 30 water. The manufacturer of the antifreeze suggests that for summer driving, optimal cooling of the engine is obtained with only 50 antifreeze.

If the capacity of the radiator is 4.4 liters, how much coolant (in liters) must be drained and replaced with pure water to reduce the antifreeze concentration to 50? Round to the nearest hundredth of a liter. L

solution.p: This is a percent problem. We know the percent that is originally antifreeze (70) and the percent we want (50). Let's call the amount to drain \displaystyle{d} (in liters). The amount of antifreeze after we drain is \displaystyle{\left({0.7}\right)}{\left({4.4}-{d}\right)}. This will be the same as the amount after we add water which is \displaystyle{0.5}{\left({4.4}\right)}. Thus we can solve \displaystyle{\left({0.7}\right)}{\left({4.4}-{d}\right)}={0.5}{\left({4.4}\right)}. The solution is \displaystyle{d}={1.2571428571429}. Rounding (because we can only measure so precisely) gives us 1.26 L.
